newsitem.title: USA: Witness accuses Democrats of searching for dirt.
newsitem.headline: Witness accuses Democrats of searching for dirt.

text.p: A Republican fundraiser testifying before the Senate committee investigating campaign finance scandals, accused Democrats Thursday of conducting an unwarranted search into his personal records.
Fred Volcansek raised a $2.1 million loan guarantee for a Republican think tank from a Hong Kong businessman in 1994. The money was transferred to the Republican Party just before the 1994 election.

In his opening statement to the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, Volcansek said he recently became aware the Commerce Department had issued a worldwide bulletin requesting information about him from all places he visited as a department official from 1989 to 1992.
He said the request came from the committee's chief democratic counsel, Alan Baron.
"Clearly my service in the Department of Commerce had nothing to do with the 1996 election and I believe it is far outside this committee's mandate," Volcansek said.
His disclosure led to an angry exchange between committee chairman Fred Thompson of Tennessee and ranking Democrat John Glenn of Ohio.
Thompson said the committee had no business "rummaging around prior activities" and owed Volcansek an apology.
Glenn said the committee owed no apology and Baron was simply trying to gather relevant background information. He said Republicans were doing exactly the same to Democratic supporters.

The committee is investigating how foreign money flowed illegally to political parties in the 1996 campaign. At the centre of its probe is Asian-American John Huang, who worked in the Clinton administration at the Commerce Department and later solicited millions of dollars in illegal contributions from Asian business interests.
The committee was expected to hear testimony from former Republican Party chairman Haley Barbour later Thursday or Friday.
